Formic acid has emerged as a promising liquid hydrogen carrier for addressing the transport and storage issues of hydrogen, owing to its high hydrogen density (4.4 wt.%) and easy-handling liquid phase. Therefore, the conversion of formic acid into hydrogen and vice versa is a significant technique. Despite the development of various metal alloy catalysts for efficient production of hydrogen from formic acid, it remains unclear how the metal alloy affects formic acid dehydrogenation from the mechanistic perspective. This study addresses this gap by investigating the alloy effect of Pd and Ag on formic acid dehydrogenation, using PdAg alloy nanoparticles supported on carbon nanotube catalysts. The PdAg alloy, analyzed using multiple characterization methods, demonstrated enhanced catalytic activity, which was maximized at a Pd:Ag molar ratio of 7:3. More importantly, temperature-dependent and kinetic isotope effect experiments demonstrated that the electronic modification of Pd by Ag improved its activity by promoting the cleavage of the CH bond of formic acid. The results suggest that the kinetic isotope effect would be a potent technique for elucidating the alloying effect, as well as providing a deeper understanding of the mechanism. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Alloying effect Formic acid Hydrogen Palladium Silver Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Hydrogen is considered the most promising energy source that can replace most of the energy sectors that currently rely on fossil fuels. However, hydrogen storage and transport are challenging due to its flammability and low volumetric energy density, so the future of the hydrogen ecology is significantly dependent on developing hydrogen storage and transport technologies. Formic acid has a high hydrogen density (4.4 wt.% and 53 gH2/L) and is an easy-handling liquid material [1–5], making it a potential candidate for hydrogen storage and transport. As such, reactions such as direct hydrogenation of CO2 (H2 + CO2 → HCOOH) and dehydrogenation of formic acid (HCOOH → H2 + CO2) have been extensively studied to store hydrogen in formic acid and extract hydrogen from formic acid, respectively [6–13]. In particular, aqueous-phase formic acid dehydrogenation is an exothermic reaction that can occur spontaneously under ambient conditions, enabling its application to portable devices where external heat sources to extract hydrogen from hydrogen-containing materials cannot be applied. Palladium (Pd) is a highly active metal in aqueous-phase formic acid dehydrogenation, and thereby, numerous Pd-based catalysts have been developed to improve the efficiency of hydrogen production from formic acid. [14–18]. Various methods, such as alloy formation, modification of supports by dopants or metal oxides, and addition of additives to the reactants, have been suggested to enhance the activity of the catalysts [19–31]. Particularly for alloy or bimetallic catalysts, Pd incorporated with several other metals (e.g., Ag, Au, Cu, Co, and Ni) demonstrated much-improved activity compared to monometallic Pd [16,32–42]. This is primarily attributed to the electronic modification of Pd by additional metals, as typically demonstrated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. However, several unresolved issues remain regarding the alloy effect. One issue is the comparison of catalyst activities using turnover rates calculated based on either the total number of metals or the total number of surface metals, without considering specific active sites. However, it is essential to consider the number of specific active sites, i.e., the surface Pd atoms where the reaction can actually occur. For instance, Yamashita et al. compared the turnover numbers of CO2 hydrogenation reaction over monometallic Pd, PdAg alloy, Ag@Pd (Ag core and Pd shell), and Pd@Ag (Pd core and Ag shell) based only on the exposed Pd [7], which enabled them to independently consider the electronic modification effect of Pd by Ag on this reaction. Another unresolved issue is the lack of suggestions on how electronic modification affects the reaction from a mechanistic point of view. It appears evident from previous studies that the electronic modification of Pd by Ag enhances formic acid dehydrogenation activity, but only a few attempts have been made to understand how this electronic effect alters the reaction from a mechanistic perspective. Most recently, Yamashita et al., demonstrated that the ensemble of Pd and Ag facilitate CH bond dissociation and H2 desorption by DFT calculation combined with kinetic isotope effect experiments [43]. Still, further investigation would provide deeper insights into the alloy effect and its underlying mechanism, which could aid in the development of even more efficient catalysts. In this study, we synthesized PdAg alloy nanoparticles supported on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with varying Pd and Ag molar ratios. The formation of the alloy and electronic modification of Pd were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and XPS techniques, respectively. The number of surface (exposed) Pd sites, where formic acid dehydrogenation reaction would take place, was quantified by CO chemisorption. Then, the specific activities (turnover frequency) were calculated based on this quantification and compared them to reveal the electronic modification effect. The specific activity exhibited a continuous increase up to an optimized Pd:Ag molar ratio of 7:3 and then decreased, which was in the same order as the degree of the electronic modification observed in the XPS analysis. We conducted further experiments to measure the activation barrier and kinetic isotope effect (KIE) of each catalyst to determine how the alloying of Pd and Ag affected the reaction from a mechanistic point of view. Experimental section Chemicals Multiwalled carbon nanotube (CNT, 50 – 90 nm diameter), palladium chloride (Pd(Cl)2), silver nitrate (Ag(NO3)2), (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), trisodium citrate (Na3Cit), sodium borohydride (NaBH4), formic acid (HCOOH), sodium formate (HCOONa), formic-d acid (DCOOH) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Hydrochloric acid was obtained from Samchun Pure Chemical Co. (Seoul, South Korea). H2PdCl4 solution (0.05 M) was prepared by dissolving PdCl2 in a 0.5 M HCl solution in advance. All water used in this study was Milli-Q water with a resistivity of 18.2 MΩ·cm. Catalyst preparation A synthesis method to prepare PdAg nanoparticles supported on CNT was similar to the one used in our previous study [22]. Specifically, 0.5 g of CNT, 1 g of Na3Cit, and 1 mL of APTES were mixed in 150 mL water. The solution mixture was sonicated for 10 min and stirred at 1000 ppm for 30 min. Then, desired amounts of the Pd and Ag mixture solution (Pd+Ag: 5 wt.% with the different Pd:Ag ratios) were added to this solution. After stirring for 30 min, a NaBH4 solution (0.15 g NaBH4 in 30 mL) was introduced drop by drop to reduce Pd and Ag ions into metallic Pd and Ag. The solution was stirred for another 30 min, and the resulting powder was filtered and washed with excess water. By adding NaBH4 solution to the filtered solution, it was confirmed that all the metal precursors were impregnated on the CNT. All the synthetic steps before the filtration were conducted in the ice bath (∼ 2 ℃), because the catalysts prepared at this low temperature showed higher activity than those prepared at room temperatures (Fig. S1). The amounts of Na3Cit and APTES, stabilizing agents, were optimized to maximize the catalytic activity (Fig. S2). The resulting catalysts were named PdxAgy/CNT, where x and y represent the molar ratios of Pd and Ag, respectively. The total content of Pd and Ag was fixed at 5 wt.% while varying their molar ratios. Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted to identify the alloy formation of Pd and Ag by a powder X-ray diffractometer (Smartlab, Rigaku). The operating current and voltage were set to 30 mA and 40 kV, respectively. The scanning speed was 1 °/min with a step interval of 0.2 ° to obtain data with low signal-to-noise ratios. The electronic modification of Pd was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in the Pd region by a K-alpha instrument (Thermo Scientific, UK) equipped with AlKα µ-focused monochromatic radiation (1486.6 eV). The operating condition was 3 mA of current and 12 kV of voltage. The binding energies were corrected by fixing the binding energy of C1s at 284.5 eV. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were obtained from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at – 196 ℃ using a BELSORP-mini II instrument (BEL Japan). Pulsed CO chemisorption was conducted using a BEL-CAT-II (BEL Japan Inc.) to independently quantify the number of surface Pd atoms. Approximately 0.03 g of sample were loaded and exposed to 5 vol.% of H2/Ar gas at 100 ℃ for 0.5 h to reduce oxidized metals. Then, 5 vol.% CO/He gas was introduced by pulsed injection at 50 ℃, and the number of adsorbed CO molecules was calculated by subtracting the number of bypassed CO molecules from the number of injected CO molecules. Transmission electron microscopic images of Pd/CNT and Pd7Ag3/CNT catalysts were obtained using a scanning transmission electron microscope (JEM-ARM200F (Cs-STEM)) equipped with a cold field emission gun and a spherical aberration corrector in a condenser lens with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Reaction tests For catalytic activity measurement, a semi-batch reaction system was utilized, which was adopted from our previous studies [22,23,44]. In this system, 0.03 g of the sample was loaded into a two-necked reactor that was connected to a burette filled with mineral oil. 9 mL of the reactant solution (formic acid-only or a mixture of formic acid and sodium formate) was introduced into the reactor through a rubber septum. Once the reactant was introduced, the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction occurred, and the volume of gas generated during the reaction was automatically measured by scaling the mass of the mineral oil extruded by the generated gas. The reaction temperatures and reactant compositions varied depending on the experiments and the specific conditions are presented in the captions of each figure. For kinetic isotope effect (KIE) experiments, the initial reaction rates within the first 1 min were compared under the reaction conditions, using 9 mL of 1 M formic acid (HCOOH) or 1 M formic-d acid (DCOOH) at 60 ℃. Turnover frequency The TOF values were calculated based on the total number of metal atoms (Pd+ Ag) or the number of surface Pd atoms. T O F ( h − 1 ) = P · V 2 · R · T · N · t where P is the atmospheric pressure (1 atm), V is the volume of gas generated during the reaction at first 1 min, R is the gas constant (0.082 L·atm·K −1·mol−1), T is the temperature of the gas (298 K), and t is 1/60 hr. N is the total number of metal atoms (Pd + Ag) or the number of surface Pd atoms quantified from CO chemisorption. Results and discussion Characterization of catalysts Before synthesizing PdAg/CNT catalysts, we optimized the synthetic conditions to maximize catalytic activity. The catalytic activity could be maximized by reducing the synthesis temperatures and by optimizing the amount of trisodium citrate (Na3Cit) and (3-Aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), both of which are stabilizing agents (Figs. S1 and S2). Using these optimized synthetic conditions, PdAg/CNT catalysts were synthesized while varying molar ratios of Pd and Ag. The physicochemical properties of the PdAg/CNT catalysts were determined by various characterization methods. Fig. 1 a presents the overall XRD patterns of the PdAg/CNT catalysts, displaying various peaks attributed to different crystalline phases of materials. The peaks at around 26, 43, 44.5, and 78 ° corresponded to the CNT, which served as a support for the PdAg nanoparticles. The metallic Ag was observed in the XRD pattern of Ag/CNT with peaks located at around 38 and 44 °, while the metallic Pd peak in the XRD pattern of Pd/CNT was mainly located at around 40 ° [45,46]. XRD is one of the most reliable bulk techniques for determining the formation of alloys [39,47]. When two or more metals are alloyed, the diffraction patterns observed in XRD will fall in the middle range of peaks of each metal, and if there are a large number of crystallites composed only of single metal, the XRD pattern may show distinct peaks corresponding to that metal. Therefore, the presence of peaks in the middle range of peaks of each metal and the absence of peaks from each metal strongly indicates the formation of alloy. Fig. 1b represents the magnified XRD patterns in the range of the metallic Pd and Ag. It shows the combined peak of Pd and Ag was shifted from 40 ° of metallic Pd to 38 ° of metallic Ag with the increase in the Ag/Pd molar ratios, indicating that Pd and Ag were well successfully alloyed [34,38,39,48]. In addition to XRD analysis, alloy formation can also be identified by changes in the electronic state of Pd originating from Ag, which can be determined by XPS [7,24,39–42]. Fig. 2 displays the XPS spectra of the PdAg/CNT catalysts in Pd 3d region in, calibrated by C 1 s (Fig. S3a). It reveals that the Pd binding energy shifted to a lower energy (red shift) with increasing Ag/Pd ratios up to 3/7 (Pd7Ag3/CNT), while a further increase in the Ag ratio induced a smaller shift. Meanwhile, we observed that the binding energy of Ag shifted to the opposite direction in the same trend, strongly suggesting that the interaction between Pd and Ag induced the electron modification of Pd (Fig. S3b). Based on the results obtained, a molar ratio of 7:3 for Pd:Ag represents an optimal alloy configuration for inducing the electronic modification of Pd the most. Considering that the electronic structure shared between two metals would be maximized at a certain metal ratio while minimized at a nearly monometallic phase, such a volcanic trend of binding energy shift was reasonable. In addition, the PdAg/CNT catalysts contained amine-functional groups originating from APTES (Fig. S3c), which would facilitate deprotonation of HCOOH. However, it is worth noting that all catalysts had the same amount of the amine-functional groups (Table S1) because the same concentration of APTES was used during the catalyst synthesis. Hence, we could exclude their effect on difference in activity depending on the Pd:Ag ratios. Fig. 3 a and b show the TEM images of Pd/CNT and Pd7Ag3/CNT, respectively. Pd7Ag3/CNT catalyst was chosen as the representative sample of PdAg alloy catalysts, because it exhibited the most significant difference in the electronic state of Pd (Fig. 2) as well as it had a high Ag/Pd ratio. The particle size distribution and average particle sizes of both catalysts were determined by counting more than 200 particles. Surprisingly, despite the considerable difference in the composition and electronic state of Pd in both catalysts, the average particle sizes of Pd/CNT and Pd7Ag3/CNT were almost identical with the values of 3.0 nm and 3.1 nm, respectively. This suggests that the stabilizing agents, Na3Cit and APTES, used in the preparation of the catalysts were effective in controlling the particle size. Furthermore, the absence of complex micro- and meso‑porosity of CNT would provide a similar environment for the anchoring of metal to the support, leading to a uniform particle size distribution. Since both catalysts had no significant difference in particle size, it would be assumed that the particle size of PdAg would not vary depending on the molar ratio of Pd and Ag. Furthermore, we could ignore the effect of particle size on the reaction that would significantly affect the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction [44]. The structures of the PdAg/CNT catalysts were analyzed using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S4). The pristine CNT had a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 22 m2/g, while the PdAg/CNT catalysts had surface areas ranging from 27 to 30 m2/g. Typically, pore blocking by impregnated metal reduces the surface area of the supports. However, considering that CNT has no pores, this is not a surprising result because the surface of the particles would increase the surface area of the samples. It should also be noted that the absence of micropores in CNT would exclude the possibility of fouling of reactants or products which was proposed as one of deactivation causes [49]. Formic acid dehydrogenation over PdAg/CNT catalysts The performance of PdAg/CNT catalysts in aqueous-phase formic acid dehydrogenation reactions was evaluated using a formic acid (FA)-only solution and a mixture solution of FA and sodium formate (SF) of a molar ratio of 1:1. Fig. 4 a and c illustrate the volume of gas generated during the reactions with FA-only and FA-SF mixture solutions, respectively. The Pd/CNT catalyst displayed decent catalytic activity under both reaction conditions, producing a substantial amount of hydrogen gas. In contrast, the Ag/CNT catalyst did not produce any hydrogen gas, while the PdAg/CNT catalysts exhibited higher or lower hydrogen production compared to Pd/CNT. This suggests that Pd is the active metal and Ag would function as the promoting metal when used with Pd for this reaction. The catalytic activities of the PdAg/CNT catalysts were found to be dependent on the Pd:Ag molar ratios, displaying a volcanic trend. This volcanic trend depending on the Pd:Ag molar ratios is consistent with previous studies [32,36,37,40,41]. The catalytic activity of the PdAg/CNT catalysts was initially improved due to the synergetic effect of Pd and Ag. However, as the Ag/Pd molar ratios increased, the total amount of Pd, the active metal in this reaction, decreased. Consequently, the catalytic activity when using the same amount of total metals, depending on the Pd:Ag molar ratios, typically showed volcanic curves. The turnover frequency (TOF) values calculated based on the total number of metals (= Pd + Ag) show the volcanic trends, as displayed in Figs. 4b and 4d with red bars. However, there was a distinctive difference when using the FA-only and the FA-SF mixture solutions as reactants. In case of using the FA-only solution as a reactant (Fig. 4b), the TOF values increased with increasing Ag content up to a maximum at a Pd:Ag molar ratio of 9:1 and then decreased at higher Pd:Ag ratios. On the other hand, when the FA-SF mixture solution was used as a reactant (Fig. 4d), the maximum TOF value was observed over PdAg/CNT catalyst with a Pd:Ag molar ratio of 8:2. In addition, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis of the produced gasses over Pd/CNT and Pd7Ag3/CNT demonstrated revealed the absence of CO in the produced gas (Fig. S5), indicating that the dehydration of formic acid (HCOOH → H2O + CO) was negligible for the formic acid decomposition over PdAg/CNT catalysts. We conducted similar experiments using the mixture of FA and SF with different molar ratios (Figs. S6 and S7). Similar to the result of Figs. 4b and 4d, the Pd:Ag ratio resulting in the maximum TOF value was greatly dependent on the ratios of FA and SF. This ambiguous correlation between Pd:Ag ratio and the activity, varied with the molar ratio of FA and SF, would be mainly because the number of active sites was not taken into account. In order to elucidate the alloying effect of Ag on Pd more precisely, it is important to compare the catalytic activities that are calculated based on the number of active sites, specifically the surface Pd atoms. CO chemisorption analysis was conducted to independently measure the surface Pd sites in the PdAg/CNT catalysts, similar to the previous work by Yamashita's group [7]. Since the Ag/CNT catalyst did not chemisorb CO molecules at all (Fig. S8), the amount of chemisorbed CO molecules on the PdAg/CNT catalysts could be simply used to quantify the amount of surface Pd atoms. Then, the activities of the active sites of the PdAg/CNT catalysts were compared using turnover frequency (TOF) values calculated based on the number of surface Pd atoms (Table 1 ), as shown in Fig. 4b and d with blue bars. In contrast to the results of TOF values based on the total number of metals (the red bars in Fig. 4b and d), the TOF values based on the surface Pd sites exhibited a different trend. The maximum TOF values calculated by the total number of metals were significantly influenced by the FA:SF ratio. However, irrespective of the different FA:SF molar ratios (Figs. 4b, d, S6b, and S7b), all the TOF values calculated by the surface Pd sites increased as the Pd:Ag molar ratios were changed from 10:0 to 7:3, and then decreased as the Ag content increased further. In other words, the Pd:Ag ratio maximizing the TOF was not dependent on the molar ratio of FA and SF. Such a consistent trend of TOF values calculated from the surface Pd sites, which was independent of the Pd:Ag molar ratios of the reactant, is much more reasonable. It is because the addition of SF only increases the number of formate anions, which are the starting reactant of formic acid dehydrogenation [50]. Therefore, it should be emphasized that the activity of the alloy catalyst must be compared only by considering the active sites, not all metal atoms in the catalysts. More importantly, this trend of TOF which has the maximum value at the Pd:Ag molar ratio of 7:3 can be directly correlated with the electronic modification shown in the XPS spectra of Fig. 2, where the most significant binding energy shift of Pd 3d was observed for the Pd7Ag3/CNT catalyst. Taking into account the specific activity of the active Pd atoms, specifically the surface Pd atoms, it became evident that the observed improvement in catalytic activity was primarily due to the electronic modification of Pd by Ag. Although this improvement through electronic modification has been previously observed by several other research groups [32,36,37,40,41], establishing a clear correlation between electronic modification and catalytic improvement was challenging, likely due to the lack of information on the number of active Pd sites. In addition, despite the promising results obtained in previous studies, the lack of mechanistic investigations has limited the comprehension of the alloying effect in bimetallic catalysts. To address this gap, we conducted further investigations to elucidate how the electronic modification of Pd enhances the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction. Scheme 1 presents a proposed reaction pathway for formic acid dehydrogenation by our intensive mechanistic study [50]. The reaction pathway starts with the deprotonation of formic acid via acid-base equilibrium to produce formate anions. Then, formate anions adsorb on the active sites, followed by CH bond cleavage to produce carbon dioxide and hydride. Electron transfer between the hydride and adsorbed proton occurs spontaneously. Finally, the hydrogen atoms are combined and desorbed from the active sites, which is suggested to be the rate-limiting step [36,44,51–53]. It should be mentioned that the acid-base equilibrium (Reaction step 1) and the adsorption steps (Reaction steps 2 and 4) would be quasi-equilibrated. The electronic modification of Pd in PdAg/CNT catalysts can potentially influence either the reaction pathway or the rate-limiting step of the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction. To gain further insights into the effect of electronic modification on the reaction mechanism, we performed temperature-dependent experiments with the FA-only solution and the mixture solution of FA and SF (Figs. S9 and S10), and acquired the apparent activation energies (Ea,app). Fig. 5 presents the Ea,app values of the PdAg/CNT catalysts with different Pd:Ag molar ratios. There was a slight decrease in Ea,app (∼ 4–5 kJ/mol) when using the mixture solution of FA and SF instead of the FA-only solution. Based on the reaction scheme and our previous work, formic acid dehydrogenation reaction is approximately first-order dependent on formate anion and proton [50]. In principle, the reactant concentration should not affect the activation barrier. However, considering that the reaction takes place in the aqueous phase, the temperature-dependent dissociation of formic acid and water can influence the concentrations of formate and proton species. It is important to note that the FA-SF mixture solution acts as a buffer solution, resulting in a much smaller concentration difference in formate anion and proton with temperature compared to the FA-only solution. This difference in concentration variation can contribute to the slight discrepancy in the Ea,app between the FA-only solution and the FA-SF mixture solution, as previously observed [22,50,54]. However, it is much more significant that the difference between the Ea,app values of the catalysts was negligible, suggesting that the electronic modification of Pd through alloying with Ag did not significantly alter either the reaction pathway or the rate-limiting step (Reaction Step 5) of the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction. Kinetic isotope effect (KIE) experiments are a powerful tool in determining the reaction pathway and rate-limiting step of chemical reactions. In our previous study, KIE experiments were used successfully to establish the reaction pathway and rate-limiting step of formic acid dehydrogenation [50]. The KIE experiment can also be carried out to investigate the alloy effect. The KIE value, defined as the ratio of the rate constant ( k H ) for reaction with a molecule to that ( k D ) with a deuterium-substituted molecule, can be expressed using the equation of k H / k D = exp ( ( Δ G H ‡ − Δ G D ‡ ) / R T ) , where Δ G H ‡ and Δ G D ‡ are Gibbs free energies of activation of the reactions with the molecule and the deuterium-substituted molecule, respectively, while R is a gas constant and T is the temperature [55]. When a hydrogen (H) of a molecule is replaced with a deuterium atom (D), the vibrational state of the molecule is stabilized because the vibrational frequency of the molecular vibration ( v ) is reduced by a heavier atom (D). However, the degree of stabilization depends on the particular energy state of the molecule. For example, in the CH bond cleavage step of a reaction, the strength of the CH bond is stronger in the initial state of the reaction compared to that in the transition state. The vibration frequency is proportional to the force constant (k) (or bond strength) of chemical bond, so the difference between the zero-point energies (ZPEs) of a hydrogen-containing molecule (H-molecule) and a deuterium-substituted molecule (D-molecule) is much greater at the initial states than at the transition state [56,57]. As a result, the Gibbs free energy of activation required for the CH bond cleavage step would be higher for d-molecule than for H-molecule ( Δ G H , I S 1 ‡ < Δ G D , I S 1 ‡ in Scheme 2 ). This difference in the Gibbs free energy of activation between H- and d-molecules leads to a KIE value that is generally greater than 1. We extended this principle of KIE to understanding the reasons for the different activities of the PdAg/CNT catalysts. The KIE experiments were performed by replacing HCOOH with DCOOH (Fig. S11) because either adsorption of formate anion (Reaction Step 2) or the cleavage of CH bond (Reaction Step 3) would be the only reaction steps where the effect of Pd modification could be involved. The KIE values obtained for the PdAg/CNT catalysts as a function of the Pd:Ag molar ratio are shown in Fig. 6 . As expected, the activity was reduced when using DCOOH due to the increased activation barriers for either the CH bond cleavage step or the subsequentsteps where deuterium atoms could participate through the stabilized molecular vibration. Consequently, the KIE values were found to be greater than 1 for all catalysts. However, interestingly, we found that the degree of KIE for the deuterium-substituted formic acid was dependent on the Pd:Ag molar ratio. The KIE values continued to decrease until the Pd:Ag molar ratio reached 7:3 and remained nearly constant for Pd:Ag molar ratios between 7:3 and 6:4. The smaller KIE value observed at higher Ag/Pd molar ratios may be attributed to weaker CH bond strength. This can be explained by considering the energy diagram of CH bond cleavage shown in Scheme 2, which includes two initial states (IS1 and IS2) with different CH bond strengths. The initial state 1 (IS1) represents the energy state of a molecule that has a strong CH bond and is therefore located at a more stabilized energy level. In contrast, the initial state 2 (IS2) is the energy state of a molecule with a weak CH bond so that it is placed at a less stable energy level. Therefore, the difference in the Gibbs free energy of activation between H-molecule and d-molecule becomes smaller when the CH bond strength becomes weaker, as shown in Scheme 2 ( Δ G H , I S 1 ‡ − Δ G D , I S 1 ‡ > Δ G H , I S 2 ‡ − Δ G D , I S 2 ‡ ). This signifies that the weaker CH bond will have lower KIE values. The decreased KIE values with increasing the Ag/Pd molar ratios in Fig. 6 indicate that the CH bond strength of the adsorbed formate (HCOO−*) became weaker over the PdAg/CNT catalysts with higher Ag/Pd molar ratios. This weakening of the CH bond can be attributed to the larger electronic modification of Pd, as shown in Fig. 2. Subsequently, the weaker CH bond facilitated the CH bond cleavage of adsorbed HCOO−, thereby enhancing the overall reaction activity. Yamashita et al. also arrived at a similar conclusion that Pd alloyed with either Ag or Cr would have a lower energy barrier for CH bond dissociation based on DFT calculation and KIE experiments [43]. In summary, the alloying effect of Ag on Pd can be explained as follows: alloy formation of Pd with Ag caused electronic modification of Pd, which excited the molecular orbital of the adsorbed HCOO− to have a weaker CH bond. This, in turn, facilitated the CH bond cleavage of HCOO−*, resulting in enhanced activity of formic acid dehydrogenation over the PdAg/CNT catalysts. Conclusion We investigated the effect of Ag alloying on Pd for the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction using PdAg/CNT catalysts with different Pd and Ag molar ratios. Our characterization and activity measurements, based on the number of active sites, revealed that the electronic modification of Pd by alloyed Ag improved the catalytic activity. Furthermore, activation barrier measurements and kinetic isotope effect experiments provided evidence that this improved activity was due to the alloyed PdAg promoting the excitation of the CH bond in adsorbed formate (HCOO−*), which facilitated CH bond cleavage. These insights contribute to a deeper understanding of the catalytic formic acid dehydrogenation reaction in aqueous phase and provide a new approach for investigating the metal-alloying effects that have been extensively employed in various catalytic processes. coredata.dc:description: Formic acid has emerged as a promising liquid hydrogen carrier for addressing the transport and storage issues of hydrogen, owing to its high hydrogen density (4.4 wt.%) and easy-handling liquid phase. Therefore, the conversion of formic acid into hydrogen and vice versa is a significant technique. Despite the development of various metal alloy catalysts for efficient production of hydrogen from formic acid, it remains unclear how the metal alloy affects formic acid dehydrogenation from the mechanistic perspective. This study addresses this gap by investigating the alloy effect of Pd and Ag on formic acid dehydrogenation, using PdAg alloy nanoparticles supported on carbon nanotube catalysts. The PdAg alloy, analyzed using multiple characterization methods, demonstrated enhanced catalytic activity, which was maximized at a Pd:Ag molar ratio of 7:3. More importantly, temperature-dependent and kinetic isotope effect experiments demonstrated that the electronic modification of Pd by Ag improved its activity by promoting the cleavage of the CH bond of formic acid. The results suggest that the kinetic isotope effect would be a potent technique for elucidating the alloying effect, as well as providing a deeper understanding of the mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Elucidating the alloying effect of PdAg/CNT catalysts on formic acid dehydrogenation with kinetic isotope effect
